nodes.bodyText:
Yes, you may, as the choice of verbs was interesting. I went with POST for the login for two reasons:

So that it could be used if someone just wanted a simple form login kind of idea - and hence why I went with query params rather than JSON body; and
As it does essentially 'create' a new session on the server.

So with that in mind, using PUT at the other end seemed to make sense as it's updating a session. The other option could be DELETE as it's kind of removing a session, but really a session seems to remain in the oEQ Auth paradigm - as you can see we change the session to be as 'guest'.
But with that all now in mind, I'd be interested to hear your thoughts? Does the above play out, or should we change it?

nodes.bodyText: Will we use  io.github.openequella.rest.XXX as package names for REST Api tests created in the future ?

We might, we'll have to see how things play out.
The current REST tests are all token based and are thereby possibly more focused towards system integration as opposed to end user use via a simple login. However the future extensions we'll be focusing on will be to support the new UI so it may make more sense to do them utilising this new login endpoint.
If things do play out that way, then we'll probably create a simpler version of AbstractRestTest and place them here. Plus, then we might be able to avoid also needing to interact with a browser and so then the tests can run much after.
An although it may not influence if we stay with this package name, it would also possibly make sense to write the new tests in Scala - and maybe with ScalaTest - seeing we plan to write all the endpoints with Scala. 🤔
So I'm afraid no black and white answer there. But definitely some things to keep in mind when we write the next one. ;)
